content.title: Neurogenic TOS Detailed
content.description: Detailed evaluation and management of neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome

key_concepts.details: Upper extremity pain, paresthesias, weakness; typically ulnar distribution
Most common; symptoms without objective neurologic findings
Rare; objective atrophy/weakness, often lower trunk involvement (Gilliatt-Sumner hand)
Physical therapy first; surgery (scalenectomy, first rib resection) if refractory

content.clinical_significance: 95% of TOS is neurogenic; diagnosis often challenging

primary_sources: Sanders RJ et al. J Vasc Surg 2007
